statement:
If $A$ is a commutative ring, and $\operatorname{dim}$ denotes Krull
dimension, then $$\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{dim}(A)+1\leq \operatorname{dim}(A[x])\leq 2\operatorname{dim}(A)+1.\end{aligned}$$

It is known (see [@Seid],[@Seid2]) that for any $k\geq 0$ and $n$ with
$k+1\leq n\leq 2k+1$, there exists a ring $A$ such that $\dim A=k$ and
$\dim A[x]=n$.

[9]{} A. Seidenberg, *A note on the dimension theory of rings.* Pacific
J. of Mathematics, Volume 3 (1953), 505-512. A. Seidenberg, *On the
dimension theory of rings (II).* Pacific J. of Mathematics, Volume 4
(1954), 603-614.
names: bound on the Krull dimension of polynomial rings
